title: A Legend of Montrose

title: A Legend of Montrose

text: the reign of James IV., a great feud between the powerful families
title: A Legend of Montrose

text: of Drummond and Murray divided Perthshire. The former, being the most
title: A Legend of Montrose

title: A Legend of Montrose

title: A Legend of Montrose

title: A Legend of Montrose

title: A Legend of Montrose

title: A Legend of Montrose

title: A Legend of Montrose

title: A Legend of Montrose

title: A Legend of Montrose

title: A Legend of Montrose

text: half century. Before that period, the Lowlanders were as constantly
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: engaged in war as the mountaineers, and were incomparably better
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: disciplined and armed. The favourite Scottish order of battle somewhat
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: resembled the Macedonian phalanx. Their infantry formed a compact body,
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: armed with long spears, impenetrable even to the men-at-arms of the age,
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: though well mounted, and arrayed in complete proof. It may easily
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: be conceived, therefore, that their ranks could not be broken by the
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: disorderly charge of Highland infantry armed for close combat only, with
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: swords, and ill furnished with missile weapons, and having no artillery
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: whatever.
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: This habit of fight was in a great measure changed by the introduction
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: of muskets into the Scottish Lowland service, which, not being as yet
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: combined with the bayonet, was a formidable weapon at a distance, but
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: gave no assurance against the enemy who rushed on to close quarters. The
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: pike, indeed, was not wholly disused in the Scottish army; but it was no
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: longer the favourite weapon, nor was it relied upon as formerly by those
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: in whose hands it was placed; insomuch that Daniel Lupton, a tactician
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: of the day, has written a book expressly upon the superiority of the
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: musket. This change commenced as early as the wars of Gustavus Adolphus,
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: whose marches were made with such rapidity, that the pike was very soon
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: thrown aside in his army, and exchanged for fire-arms. A circumstance
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: which necessarily accompanied this change, as well as the establishment
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: of standing armies, whereby war became a trade, was the introduction of
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: a laborious and complicated system of discipline, combining a variety
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: of words of command with corresponding operations and manoeuvres, the
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: neglect of any one of which was sure to throw the whole into confusion.
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: War therefore, as practised among most nations of Europe, had assumed
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: much more than formerly the character of a profession or mystery, to
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: which previous practice and experience were indispensable requisites.
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: Such was the natural consequence of standing armies, which had almost
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: everywhere, and particularly in the long German wars, superseded what
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: may be called the natural discipline of the feudal militia.
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: The Scottish Lowland militia, therefore, laboured under a double
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: disadvantage when opposed to Highlanders. They were divested of the
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: spear, a weapon which, in the hands of their ancestors, had so often
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: repelled the impetuous assaults of the mountaineer; and they were
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: subjected to a new and complicated species of discipline, well adapted,
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: perhaps, to the use of regular troops, who could be rendered completely
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: masters of it, but tending only to confuse the ranks of citizen
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: soldiers, by whom it was rarely practised, and imperfectly understood.
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: So much has been done in our own time in bringing back tactics to their
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: first principles, and in getting rid of the pedantry of war, that it
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: is easy for us to estimate the disadvantages under which a half-trained
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: militia laboured, who were taught to consider success as depending upon
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: their exercising with precision a system of tactics, which they probably
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: only so far comprehended as to find out when they were wrong, but
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: without the power of getting right again. Neither can it be denied,
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: that, in the material points of military habits and warlike spirit,
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: the Lowlanders of the seventeenth century had sunk far beneath their
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: Highland countrymen.
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: From the earliest period down to the union of the crowns, the whole
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: kingdom of Scotland, Lowlands as well as Highlands, had been the
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: constant scene of war, foreign and domestic; and there was probably
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: scarce one of its hardy inhabitants, between the age of sixteen and
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: sixty, who was not as willing in point of fact as he was literally bound
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: in law, to assume arms at the first call of his liege lord, or of a
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: royal proclamation. The law remained the same in sixteen hundred and
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: forty-five as a hundred years before, but the race of those subjected to
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: it had been bred up under very different feelings. They had sat in quiet
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: under their vine and under their fig-tree, and a call to battle involved
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: a change of life as new as it was disagreeable. Such of them, also, who
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: lived near unto the Highlands, were in continual and disadvantageous
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: contact with the restless inhabitants of those mountains, by whom their
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: cattle were driven off, their dwellings plundered, and their persons
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: insulted, and who had acquired over them that sort of superiority
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: arising from a constant system of aggression. The Lowlanders, who lay
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: more remote, and out of reach of these depredations, were influenced by
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: the exaggerated reports circulated concerning the Highlanders, whom,
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: as totally differing in laws, language, and dress, they were induced
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: to regard as a nation of savages, equally void of fear and of humanity.
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: These various prepossessions, joined to the less warlike habits of the
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: Lowlanders, and their imperfect knowledge of the new and complicated
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: system of discipline for which they had exchanged their natural mode
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: of fighting, placed them at great disadvantage when opposed to the
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: Highlander in the field of battle. The mountaineers, on the contrary,
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: with the arms and courage of their fathers, possessed also their simple
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: and natural system of tactics, and bore down with the fullest confidence
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: upon an enemy, to whom anything they had been taught of discipline was,
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: like Saul's armour upon David, a hinderance rather than a help, "because
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: they had not proved it."
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: It was with such disadvantages on the one side, and such advantages on
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: the other, to counterbalance the difference of superior numbers and the
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: presence of artillery and cavalry, that Montrose encountered the army of
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: Lord Elcho upon the field of Tippermuir. The Presbyterian clergy had not
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: been wanting in their efforts to rouse the spirit of their followers,
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: and one of them, who harangued the troops on the very day of battle,
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: hesitated not to say, that if ever God spoke by his mouth, he promised
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: them, in His name, that day, a great and assured victory. The cavalry
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: and artillery were also reckoned sure warrants of success, as the
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: novelty of their attack had upon former occasions been very discouraging
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: to the Highlanders. The place of meeting was an open heath, and the
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: ground afforded little advantage to either party, except that it allowed
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: the horse of the Covenanters to act with effect.
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: A battle upon which so much depended, was never more easily decided.
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: The Lowland cavalry made a show of charging; but, whether thrown into
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: disorder by the fire of musketry, or deterred by a disaffection to
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: the service said to have prevailed among the gentlemen, they made no
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: impression on the Highlanders whatever, and recoiled in disorder from
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: ranks which had neither bayonets nor pikes to protect them. Montrose
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: saw, and instantly availed himself of this advantage. He ordered his
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: whole army to charge, which they performed with the wild and desperate
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: valour peculiar to mountaineers. One officer of the Covenanters alone,
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: trained in the Italian wars, made a desperate defence upon the right
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: wing. In every other point their line was penetrated at the first onset;
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: and this advantage once obtained, the Lowlanders were utterly unable to
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: contend at close quarters with their more agile and athletic enemies.
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: Many were slain on the held, and such a number in the pursuit, that
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: above one-third of the Covenanters were reported to have fallen; in
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: which number, however, must be computed a great many fat burgesses who
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: broke their wind in the flight, and thus died without stroke of sword.
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: [We choose to quote our authority for a fact so singular:--"A great many
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: burgesses were killed--twenty-five householders in St. Andrews--many
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: were bursten in the flight, and died without stroke."--See Baillie's
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: Letters, vol. ii. page 92.]
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: The victors obtained possession of Perth, and obtained considerable sums
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: of money, as well as ample supplies of arms and ammunition. But
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: those advantages were to be balanced against an almost insurmountable
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: inconvenience that uniformly attended a Highland army. The clans could
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: be in no respect induced to consider themselves as regular soldiers,
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: or to act as such. Even so late as the year 1745-6, when the Chevalier
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: Charles Edward, by way of making an example, caused a soldier to be shot
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: for desertion, the Highlanders, who composed his army, were affected as
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: much by indignation as by fear. They could not conceive any principle
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: of justice upon which a man's life could be taken, for merely going home
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: when it did not suit him to remain longer with the army. Such had been
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: the uniform practice of their fathers. When a battle was over, the
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: campaign was, in their opinion, ended; if it was lost, they sought
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: safety in their mountains--if won, they returned there to secure their
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: booty. At other times they had their cattle to look after, and their
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: harvests to sow or reap, without which their families would have
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: perished for want. In either case, there was an end of their services
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: for the time; and though they were easily enough recalled by the
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: prospect of fresh adventures and more plunder, yet the opportunity
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: of success was, in the meantime, lost, and could not afterwards be
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: recovered. This circumstance serves to show, even if history had not
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: made us acquainted with the same fact, that the Highlanders had never
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: been accustomed to make war with the view of permanent conquest, but
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: only with the hope of deriving temporary advantage, or deciding some
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: immediate quarrel. It also explains the reason why Montrose, with all
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: his splendid successes, never obtained any secure or permanent footing
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: in the Lowlands, and why even those Lowland noblemen and gentlemen, who
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: were inclined to the royal cause, showed diffidence and reluctance to
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: join an army of a character so desultory and irregular, as might lead
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: them at all times to apprehend that the Highlanders securing themselves
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: by a retreat to their mountains, would leave whatever Lowlanders might
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: have joined them to the mercy of an offended and predominant enemy. The
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: same consideration will also serve to account for the sudden marches
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: which Montrose was obliged to undertake, in order to recruit his army in
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: the mountains, and for the rapid changes of fortune, by which we often
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: find him obliged to retreat from before those enemies over whom he had
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: recently been victorious. If there should be any who read these tales
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: for any further purpose than that of immediate amusement, they will find
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: these remarks not unworthy of their recollection.
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: It was owing to such causes, the slackness of the Lowland loyalists and
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: the temporary desertion of his Highland followers, that Montrose found
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: himself, even after the decisive victory of Tippermuir, in no condition
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: to face the second army with which Argyle advanced upon him from the
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: westward. In this emergency, supplying by velocity the want of strength,
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: he moved suddenly from Perth to Dundee, and being refused admission into
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: that town, fell northward upon Aberdeen, where he expected to be joined
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: by the Gordons and other loyalists. But the zeal of these gentlemen
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: was, for the time, effectually bridled by a large body of Covenanters,
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: commanded by the Lord Burleigh, and supposed to amount to three thousand
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: men. These Montrose boldly attacked with half their number. The battle
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: was fought under the walls Of the city, and the resolute valour of
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: Montrose's followers was again successful against every disadvantage.
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: But it was the fate of this great commander, always to gain the glory,
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: but seldom to reap the fruits of victory. He had scarcely time to repose
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: his small army in Aberdeen, ere he found, on the one hand, that the
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: Gordons were likely to be deterred from joining him, by the reasons we
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: have mentioned, with some others peculiar to their chief, the Marquis
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: of Huntly; on the other hand, Argyle, whose forces had been augmented by
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: those of several Lowland noblemen, advanced towards Montrose at the head
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: of an army much larger than he had yet had to cope with. These troops
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: moved, indeed, with slowness, corresponding to the cautious character
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: of their commander; but even that caution rendered Argyle's approach
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: formidable, since his very advance implied, that he was at the head of
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: an army irresistibly superior.
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: There remained one mode of retreat open to Montrose, and he adopted
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: it. He threw himself into the Highlands, where he could set pursuit
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: at defiance, and where he was sure, in every glen, to recover those
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: recruits who had left his standard to deposit their booty in their
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: native fastnesses. It was thus that the singular character of the
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: army which Montrose commanded, while, on the one hand, it rendered his
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: victory in some degree nugatory, enabled him, on the other, under the
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: most disadvantageous circumstances, to secure his retreat, recruit
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: his forces, and render himself more formidable than ever to the enemy,
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: before whom he had lately been unable to make a stand.
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: On the present occasion he threw himself into Badenoch, and rapidly
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: traversing that district, as well as the neighbouring country of Athole,
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: he alarmed the Covenanters by successive attacks upon various unexpected
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: points, and spread such general dismay, that repeated orders were
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: dispatched by the Parliament to Argyle, their commander, to engage, and
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: disperse Montrose at all rates.
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: These commands from his superiors neither suited the haughty spirit, nor
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: the temporizing and cautious policy, of the nobleman to whom they were
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: addressed. He paid, accordingly, no regard to them, but limited his
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: efforts to intrigues among Montrose's few Lowland followers, many of
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: whom had become disgusted with the prospect of a Highland campaign,
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: which exposed their persons to intolerable fatigue, and left their
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: estates at the Covenanters' mercy. Accordingly, several of them left
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: Montrose's camp at this period. He was joined, however, by a body of
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: forces of more congenial spirit, and far better adapted to the situation
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: in which he found himself. This reinforcement consisted of a large body
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: of Highlanders, whom Colkitto, dispatched for that purpose, had levied
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: in Argyleshire. Among the most distinguished was John of Moidart, called
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: the Captain of Clan Ranald, with the Stewarts of Appin, the Clan Gregor,
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: the Clan M'Nab, and other tribes of inferior distinction. By these
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: means, Montrose's army was so formidably increased, that Argyle cared no
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: longer to remain in the command of that opposed to him, but returned to
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: Edinburgh, and there threw up his commission, under pretence that his
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: army was not supplied with reinforcements and provisions in the manner
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: in which they ought to have been. From thence the Marquis returned to
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: Inverary, there, in full security, to govern his feudal vassals, and
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: patriarchal followers, and to repose himself in safety on the faith of
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: the Clan proverb already quoted--"It is a far cry to Lochow."
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: CHAPTER XVI.
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: Such mountains steep, such craggy hills,
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: His army on one side enclose:
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: The other side, great griesly gills
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: Did fence with fenny mire and moss.
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: Which when the Earl understood,
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: He council craved of captains all,
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: Who bade set forth with mournful mood,
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: And take such fortune as would fall.
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: --FLODDEN FIELD, AN ANCIENT POEM.
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: Montrose had now a splendid career in his view, provided he could obtain
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: the consent of his gallant, but desultory troops, and their independent
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: chieftains. The Lowlands lay open before him without an army adequate to
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: check his career; for Argyle's followers had left the Covenanters' host
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: when their master threw up his commission, and many other troops, tired
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: of the war, had taken the same opportunity to disband themselves. By
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: descending Strath-Tay, therefore, one of the most convenient passes from
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: the Highlands, Montrose had only to present himself in the Lowlands, in
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: order to rouse the slumbering spirit of chivalry and of loyalty which
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: animated the gentlemen to the north of the Forth. The possession of
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: these districts, with or without a victory, would give him the command
title: A Legend of Montrose
author: Scott, Walter

text: of a wealthy and fertile part of the kingdom, and would enable him, by

title: A Legend of Montrose

title: A Legend of Montrose

text: wall of Hull without liberty. "He brought me the message himself,--I
title: A Legend of Montrose

title: A Legend of Montrose

title: A Legend of Montrose

title: A Legend of Montrose

text: to seek it, either to give trust to my word, which I would not break, or
title: A Legend of Montrose

text: dealt with him, because I knew him to be a scholar."--TURNER'S MEMOIRS,
